Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then spread over the other linen cloth, with a little quantity of ointment, in accordance with the size of the hole; and place it on the member at some distance from the opening of the sinus, so that the exit of pus from it may be allayed: and do not remove the linen cloth, except after a few days.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	And yet who is above the sinus opening, he who is moved at all hours, so that it emerges from what is aggregated there from pus: and know that the virus which runs out of it is great or little; or digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And consider again the place of the sinus itself, does the Lord feel pain there, or is there no pain in it, and is there a swelling there, or is there no swelling?
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	Now when your treatment extends so long, and you see the matter that comes out over the sinus opening, then know that the sinus is already attached, or approaching attachment: then therefore حل it in the morning, or on the third day: and when you solve the wound, then change to another cloth, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if the virus comes out of the sinus after a long interval, do not despair of its attachment, for its healing approaches, for there are people who delay the generation of flesh in their wounds, and among them are those who work in an opposite way.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if it comes out after many days with undigested pus, then know that the sinus is not attached.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	But if the attachment of the sinus is delayed and its condition prolonged, then add to the exudation of medicines, indeed let the doctors make their medicine so that it be in its substance moist, and in its virtue dry: just as the ointment of daphnes, when added thereto, adds a surplus with exudation.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the greatest one that is cured, it is, so that you take the ointment of daphnes, and dissolve it with rose oil, and rub it on the old wound equally in its substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then bind the unguent thereon, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And this same action is done by you when the ointment of daphnes is not present with you, when you boil it, until it thickens, and you use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, and aloe, and olive oil: grind them all together, and powder it, and apply it to honey while it is on fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then cut a strip of cloth long enough to go across the top of the wound, and tie it tightly across the Sinus: and with the mastic poultice which you have made, until it has thickened: and dust the wound with powder, and place it on the cloth, and tie it up.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And sometimes when it is given to him long herb aristequia, and the roots of sky-lily, and it is a lily; and barley flour, and centaurea.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them simple, or ground up, wash out, and sieve themselves: and dust over the honey which you have made, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the Sinus is prolonged, and not healed with this cure: then know that there is corruption in it: or now makes an impression on the bones, or on the other hard members, or ligaments: then heal the Sinus with the cure of Fistula, as has been said.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	Về việc điều trị viêm niệu đạo và ngứa ran, và cắt ngón tay được thêm vào, và cắt
Caput XCI.	Đầu 71.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panarites là một vết viêm nhỏ xuất hiện dưới móng tay cái hoặc ngón tay, và có thể xuất hiện ở các ngón tay khác.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	Khi đó nếu tình trạng kéo dài và bị bỏ qua, và vết viêm trở nên nóng: hoặc nó bị hư hỏng, và tiết dịch nhầy, cho đến khi nó ăn mòn gốc của móng tay: và có thể nó hư hỏng toàn bộ, và có thể nó ảnh hưởng đến miệng, cho đến khi có mùi hôi thối: và làm tay bị cong, và màu của nó chuyển sang đen.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	Vì vậy khi bạn điều trị vết viêm đó, giống như đã nói ở trên về sự phân chia, và không có tác dụng chữa bệnh nào từ bạn: sau đó bạn cần phải cạo bỏ toàn bộ phần còn lại của móng tay.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Sau đó đun nóng kỹ mông sau khi điều trị.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	Vì nhiệt độ cao là điều cần thiết cho việc chữa bệnh.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Nếu xương là lành và móng tay cũng lành, và các bổ sung lỏng mỏng đang ép vào mô bên trong, và nó bắt đầu đau: sau đó bạn cần phải đặt một thứ nguyên liệu nhỏ dưới góc của móng tay bị tổn thương, và đẩy nó lên: và cắt mô với sự dễ dàng, và đặt trên phần còn lại từ các loại thuốc đốt cháy, ăn mòn, cho đến khi toàn bộ bị hư hỏng.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then this ointment care, until he heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If however the decay has already impregnated the jaw, then one should break that jaw and remove it: for indeed it is not cured while it remains in it a corrupted jaw.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see the decay and the decay to run into the finger, then cut it at one of the joints, according to what was said above in the introduction.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound, until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If however the nail is torn or struck; and there is great pain, then it is necessary that you let blood at first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with a sharp spatulium, cutting across from above to the wound.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And guard it, so that the cutting does not reach the flesh which is under the nail; for you would make happen through that a very painful injury, and it would be a cause of birth of flesh added in place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then take care of the place with him who sits with that pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The finger, however, that is born in some hands of men, perhaps is flesh all over; and perhaps there are bones in it, and perhaps there is a nail: and in some of its joints perhaps the birth is in the joint root, or perhaps it is born in certain nodules of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	So then this which is born in some nodules of the finger does not move; and that which is born at the joint of the finger, perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	That one, however, of these which is flesh, its section is easy to be made.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That is, so that you break it at its root with a spatulium blade.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But the cure for this one of whose birth is at the joint root, is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	So then abstain from cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	In that one, however, who is born in the finger at the very last joint, then it is necessary that you cut its first flesh round up to the mouth.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then cut the bone with one of those saws convenient for that purpose.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound, until it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	However the injury which has occurred to the fingers, often happens or from the birth of man, that is, he is born with it, or from the healing of a wound, or from a burn by fire and similar causes.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore it is necessary to remove this callus, until the fingers recover their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them a strip of linen, or cloth dipped in rose oil: so that they may not quickly join together and separate them: or place between them a thin piece of lead, until the place has healed as much as necessary.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And likewise if the callus which has occurred to some of the fingers with the palm, then dry this callus, according to how it is prepared and suitable for the shape of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	§ On the Incision:The Defects.
Caput XCII.	On the right side of the neck, between the Adams's apple and the angle of the jaw, there is a small opening, through which, if necessary, a straw or a needle may be inserted, to drain away any fluid that may accumulate in the throat; and in order that the skin may not be stretched tight, it should be marked from the corner of the mouth to the corner of the jaw, so as to form a kind of V. When this incision has been made, it is advisable to insert into it a large needle, so that, if necessary, any fluid which may collect in the throat may be drained away; but before doing this, care should be taken to see that the tongue does not get in the way, and then the needle should be withdrawn. When the incision has been made, care must be taken not to pierce through to the windpipe.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Veins that are deep-lying, large, and full of melancholy superfluity which occur in many parts of the body; and most of these veins are found in the legs, especially in those who walk much or work hard, and carry loads upon them.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore it is necessary that you should administer a strong treatment for the body from black cholera sometimes with a strong vomiting.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then, take a bowl of wine mixed with water, and keep it at hand.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The treatment for these veins with iron is done in two ways.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One of these methods is, so that they should sit and black blood should be drawn out.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other method is, so that a vein should be cut and all of it should be drawn out.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The section is truly performed in this way.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Now wrap the leg with warm water a lot until the thick, foul-smelling blood resolves.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then tighten the bandage around the leg from the upper side of the hip all the way down to the knee with the wound exposed.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then dry one, or two, or three wide sections in a single place.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then pour [the liquid] out, that is, draw blood from the lower part of the leg up to the top, and from the upper part let it flow onto the wound, so that the bleeding is first stopped.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then dry the leg all the way down: until you see an amount of blood that is sufficient, and which the strength of the wound-keeper allows.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then bind it up: and command him to refrain from foods that cause black cholesterol: and again instruct the patient to drain and draw blood when the veins are filled, and if it hurts the sick person.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The elevation is performed in this way.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Scrape the wound, if there are many hairs in it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then dip the wound into a bath: or wrap it in the leg of the patient with warm water until it turns red, and the veins burst: or exercise it vigorously if there is no bath available, until it warms up.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin in the direction of the wound along its length: or at the end of it near the knee, or at the lower part of it near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with a knife, and scrape the wound from all sides until it feels smooth: and you will see that it turns from red to black as it heals.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When you have thus washed the skin, you will see that it is white as a string.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then dip it under [the liquid], until it comes out and dries on the skin: hang it with a smooth, soft hook.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry another wide section next to that one with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then he removed the scabs from the upper part of the wound until it appeared.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then he washed her with water and soap, as you have done, and hung her up by the feet with another hook, as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then he dried a different section, or multiple sections, if you are able to do so.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then wash it again, and cut the last section near the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then remove it by pulling on the section that is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this, until you have completely removed it from the upper section; then cut it, or with longer sections, until you have cut through all of it when it has come loose: then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If it does not obey you when you try to remove and wash it: then insert a strong double thread under it, and tie it, and pull it out; or insert the Radium underneath: and turn your hand around all sides of it, until it has come loose.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And be careful that you do not cut yourself.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it cuts, it is difficult for you to wash it well, and it enters into the body and causes damage.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When you have completely removed it: then place it on a wound-bed that has been soaked with wine and oil and sprinkled with rose water, or just oil; and take care of it, until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	Now if the vine is contracted, and has a twist to it that lies in the way of the parts, and it is not like what we have said above in regard to the straightness: then you must find under it all the part of its twist, and the locations of its winding.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then hang it up with a hook until you have washed it all over; and be careful not to hit the section on your leg while washing it, or to cut yourself, for it will be difficult to wash well or remove from you.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	So then you are cautious.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The form of injury that heals the vine.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The form of wound that is not healing well.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.
De extractione Venae cruris.	Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uullerent venam: et est grossae flexuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret venam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.
Caput XCIII.	De extractione Venae cruris internae ut in femore, ut in thora ut in braschi ut in brachi ut in cubiti.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	Caput XCI.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	De extractione Venae femoris internae, & ad sinus uti.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	Caput XCII.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	De extractione Venae cruris externae, ad sinus uti.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Et hoc facit ut superesset, si ubi fuit et si longus est, sicut in femore: qui enim est longior a brachi, et non tantum a cubito, sed et ad pedem.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Et hoc facit ut superesset, si ubi fuit et si longus est, sicut in femore: qui enim est longior a brachi, et non tantum a cubito, sed et ad pedem.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	Et si Vena non possit ueni sua per se, et concidit in locos circumcrines, in quibus sunt moxae venarum, ut in thora, ut in braschi, ut in cubiti: tunc concidebit in locos illas moxis.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Et si Vena non possit ueni sua per se, et concidit in locos circumcrines, cum moxae venarum sunt: tunc concidebit in locos illas moxis.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	Et si Vena non possit ueni sua per se, et concidit in locos circumcrines, cum moxae venarum sunt: tunc concidebit in locos illas moxis.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not hit it with the root before it has gone out completely.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you hit it, it will be bruised, and it will go into the flesh: and it will cause an ulcer to form, and decay in place, and a bad wound.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it should be handled gently, and removed slowly, until it has gone out completely from its last part, and nothing of it remains in the body: and from this comes a vein that runs in some men for five palms and ten fingers.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And now it has come to me, because it has gone out through twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if you hit it during your treatment time: then introduce the root into its hole, and pierce it with a long one through the flesh, until all that is in it is removed out of it: and administer decay to the place with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then take care for yourself in curing those ulcers.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this Vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the joint of the foot, or in the foot itself: and it has many openings, and goes out from every opening a branch.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	So take care for her, as we have said in the division, and with what is preceded.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	Regarding the section about worms that are born under the skin, and it is called Bad Disease.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter CCIV.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This Disease is called in our language Bad Disease: because it often happens to worms, and there is one little worm that is born between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it moves in the whole body, going up and down: and it is felt by the sense when it walks on its limbs, until it breaks off at every break in the skin, and goes out.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from decay of certain kinds of earth.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	As worms and snakes, that is, earthworms, and roundworms in the belly, do.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And he fears her wickedness.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	For when he himself examined the body, and raised it up to the head, and came to a place: then perhaps it opened within him, and he departed, and destroyed his eye: and this has happened often.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	But when you are treating him, and taking him out, then that thing does not happen except with his walking, and the sensation of it itself.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore, you should hold what is above him, and what is under him with a strong constriction by the ligament.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry up on top of him, and take him out.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	That if it sinks into the flesh, and not into his whole body: then put a place on top of the spot with fire, until he dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And greater is what he fears, is her corruption, which corrupts his eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	But if you see him having already come to the head near the eye, then hold below him with a good constriction by the brow.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry up on top of him, and take him out.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that he should use his own self-cleansing with the medicines which are dissolving the bad humors of his body.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of food that generates putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	On the section about disease of Naquir.
Caput XCV.	Head 105.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This disease is called in our country Naquir, and it is a pain that happens to some member, and then it changes from one member to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And indeed I have already seen him, according to what I tell you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a sick woman in some parts of the body.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she held out her arm, and I saw swelling in the armpit of the arm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour had passed, I saw one swelling go up with fire, like the swelling of a wound, going faster than it is possible to go: so that it was like running silver, when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	The pain then came from that place and was fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then after one hour, it slid into the rest of the body until it reached the other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then he told me that he was shaking all over his body, as I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	So I was amazed at the speed of its movement from one limb to another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And indeed before that I had not seen this sickness with my eyes in such a way.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	But I saw many who were suffering from pain that was moving from one limb to another: and I did not see him with my eyes, as I saw him in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that it was, unless it is because that woman was from those who are born with scaly skin on their faces: hence this appears to be the reason for that movement of pain.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary so that it does not appear in this way in those who are healthy and have moist bodies, hidden scaliness of the skin.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When then you are healing him, and the patient feels pain: if it appears to your eye, as we have said, then squeeze him on top, and under him quickly: and dry him on top until that movement is stopped: and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	But if you do not see him with your eyes: then take care of his body with scalding, and with it what expels movements, and with pilules that turn them red, and with those made from nettle, and the like.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	Regarding the extraction of arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter LVI:
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows differ according to their kind, and according to the places from which they come out of the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	But there is a different kind: for some have large points, and some are sharp: and some are conic, and some are flat.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And of these there are those that have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And of these are the tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And from these are made stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	These indeed which are according to the members in which they fall, are according to two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or indeed the members are from the main members conjoined, such as the brain, and the heart, and the liver, and the lungs, and the kidneys, and the intestines, and the bladder, and these similar to them.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When therefore it falls into one of these members, and you see the signs of death which I shall tell you about, then you should extract that star from them, because death follows it in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when those bad signs do not appear to you, and the star is not hidden in the depth of the member, then extract it, and take care of the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For from the signs when the star falls into the brain, and penetrates the bone, and exits asiphe which is above the brain, it is: for these occur from that caustic soda, and scotoma, and vertigo, and reddening of the eyes, and inflammation, and reddening of the tongue, and spasm, and confusion of thought, and forgetfulness of cholera.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps it exits blood from the nostrils, or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is severed, and the word is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And exits from the wound's place a white, pulpy moisture.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And exits from that similar to the moisture of meat.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If therefore you see these signs, then refrain from treatment, and extract the star if it has not exited.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of the star when it falls into the heart are: that it is near the left nipple: and feels as if it were fixed in a hard place, not in a soft one.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the star has a movement similar to pulsation: and black blood runs from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And follows that coldness of extremities, and cold sweat, and fainting fits.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Know then, that death has certainly come.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of an arrow when it pierces the lung, is a frothy issue from the armpit; and the veins that follow the neck, are distended and their color changes with the nurse.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And he breathes out great wind, deep; and seeks the attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	That if the arrow falls into a wound, which is within the chest: then it is near the ribs little; and it makes a great sighing with pain, and a deep sighing: and all the limbs of the shoulders do move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if an arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps it will expel something undigested from food.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if an arrow falls into the belly, and is fixed there: it expels something from the armpit, or the rectum, or the intestine which is already broken.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	Therefore there is no hope in curing him, nor in drawing out the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	That if an arrow falls into the bladder, and expels urine: and proceeds from it something towards the outside, and its pain is stronger on the sick: then you shall know that it is deadly.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The rest of the limbs, as the face, and the neck, and the throat, and the spoons, and the support, and the spine, and the knees, and the feet, and things similar to the limbs are healed according to many dispositions: for if an arrow does not hit a blood vessel, or a nerve: and that arrow is not deadly.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you what I saw of these arrows, that it may be a sign for your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That if an arrow falls into the tear duct of a man's eye, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	And I drew it out for him by the other side, under the fat of his ear: and he was healed, and there came no harm to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I drew out another arrow from the Jew, which had fallen into his fat under his lower eyelid: and that arrow was hidden, and I could not get it out unless I cut off part of his cheekbone; and it was a great arrow among arrows of the Turks, with a soft iron; in which there were no ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	The Jew is therefore healthy, and no bad accident has befallen his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I took another arrow out of the quiver of the Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And that was an Arabic arrow, and it is the one which has ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	So I followed behind her between two spears, and she was already submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I was subtle with her, until I pulled her out: and the Christian was healthy.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I took another arrow from the man who had fallen into his belly; for we thought that he would die of it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	Afterward, however, I waited thirty days for any change in his condition, then followed behind him with the arrow; and when I had passed it over him, I looked upon it, and took it out; and he was healthy, and no bad accident happened to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man to whom the arrow had fallen on his back, and it was healed over; there was a wound on him.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	Afterward, however, he came out of prison after seven years, and the arrow had come out of the root of his thigh.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman to whom the arrow had fallen into her belly, and it was healed over; and the arrow remained within her: nor did she change by any means from her natural disposition, nor did the woman perceive any hurt in any of her natural functions.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man, to whom the arrow had fallen on his face; and it was healed over, and remained there, not causing him much pain; and similar things happened to many others.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I took out the arrow of the king's princes, which had fallen on his nose and was falling toward the right side a little; and the arrow was hidden all away.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	So I was called to cure him after the loss of the arrow for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	And I found the arrow's string very tight.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	So he himself felt a prick and pain on his right side.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I hoped that that was a spot from the tip of the bow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I therefore hoped that that was a spot from the tip of the arrow. So I laid a plaster on the place with the plaster in which there was attracting and healing power, confiding to myself that the place would heal, and it appeared to me as a sign of the bow so that I should cut over it: and no accident happened in that place indicating that the arrow had followed the place.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	So I endured with the plaster on it for many days: and no accident happened, and the bone was healed in between: and it remained ill from the space of taking it out for a day or two, until he felt the arrow one day in his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	So I put on that broken bone an acute medicine, enduring for many days until it was healed open: and when I tried to move it, I felt a little spot of the arrow which held on to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added in the opening of the wound with that acute medicine, until we could see clearly the end of the arrow: and passed from me with that time space of about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then when the bone had healed well, and it was possible for me to insert my fingers into it, and move them, and it did not comply with going out: then I did not cease to probe gently, and devise over it by means of devices, until one day I got it out with bent pins, according to the form of their shape at the end of the shaft, until I took it out.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the bone.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And those who medicate judge, that the cartilage of the nose is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	So I restored it, and the bone was healed, and the injury was healed with a complete health: and he did not hurt him in anything at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I will tell you the quality of the extraction of some arrows: to put that rule and sign over it, which I did not mention.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For the parts of this art and their distinctions are not contained in the narration; nor does this book contain them, and the prudent craftsman compares little to much: and as much as is present, he has compared it to what is absent: and found a new operation and a new instrument from descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say then that arrows do not come out of the body parts in which they are fixed, except according to two methods.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by attraction from the place from which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by the opposite part of another.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which has come out from where it entered, either is an arrow going in a fleshy place: and is attracted and comes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	That if it does not comply with the exit at the time at which it falls: then you must let it alone for a few days, until it rotten the flesh that is around it: and the attraction of it will be eased, and its exit.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And likewise if it is stuck in a bone and does not comply with you to come out, then let it go as well for a few days: and again bring it out with attraction and movement every day, until it comes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	That if it does not comply with you to come out after a few days, then you must cut off the sagitta from the bone completely with a sharp tool, until the arrow is enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then attract it and pull it out.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If however the arrow is fixed in a skull bone and has already gone into one of the vents of the cerebral bone, and appears as one of those disorders that I have mentioned: then you should refrain from attracting the arrow and let it go, until it gets used to being there after a few days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow reaches the brain, then death does not delay for long.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed except in the body of a bone and has not entered as far as the brain: and remains sick for a few days, and does not happen to him any of those disorders: then use your craft in attracting the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If it is fixed tightly, and does not obey you when you try to pull it: then apply terebinth resin around the area of the wound, as you have told me: then take care of the place until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If the arrow is already deeply embedded in the body, and hidden and concealed from sight: then try to find it with your touch.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then pull it gently with some tools that are suitable for pulling.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If you cannot get above it due to the constriction of the skin, and because of the length of the arrow deep within: and there is no bone, or nerve, or blood vessel there: then find a way above it, until the bone becomes enlarged, and it becomes possible to pull out the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	That if they are ears that are being held on, then free the flesh tightly held in them from all sides, with any device you can: and devices, if it is not possible to release the flesh in a fracture of the ears, and their contortion, until it heals.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And you when you perform the extraction of the arrow, wherever it is located, then use your twisted hands to twist it in all parts until it heals: and with the utmost care, so that the arrow does not break, and becomes difficult for you to attract it, and its extraction.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	That if you cannot get above it in one hour, then leave it for a few days, until what is around it putsrefies.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat it: for it will be relieved with poultices. But if the opposite happens to you, and the flow of blood is increased: then administer what we said in our book on treatment: and protect your skill from cutting into bone, or a nerve, or a tendon.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer devices in any way that you can to ease the removal of the arrow: and let it be with ease, and peace, or slowness, and strength, as I have told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is fitting that, when you pull out the arrow, it should be with a twist, so that it is injured according to its position, as it was located on the body with the arrow.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	For he is more skilled.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	But if you are not able to do that, then administer what is possible for you from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	But the arrow that goes out from the opposite side, or has already gone out a little toward the outside: or makes a bump at the extreme end of the dart by feeling from the upper part of the skin near it, and you see it standing out: so cut it up, and make a section according to the quantity that it holds in it the darts.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then attract it: for it becomes easy to come out.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	But if it holds itself in the bone, then turn your hand according to its roundness, until it presses the dart into the bone, and makes it strong for itself: then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: let it go for a few days: then examine it again, until it goes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	That if the wood of the dart is in it, then push it out with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	But if it has fallen on the wood, and you are to administer a push: then introduce into it an instrument that is sharp, so that the sharpness of it enters into the tail of the dart: then push it out with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	But if the dart is pushed together, then push it out with an instrument that goes into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	For the dart is relieved through that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	That if the dart is poisoned, then it is necessary, so that you do not become poisoned yourself: for this you can do if it is possible for you.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then take care of it with that which comes into contact with that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	That if the dart is falling into the chest, or the belly, or the groin, and it is close to that which you feel by trying, and it is possible for you to cut over it: then cut off, and be careful not to make an incision in the vein, or in the nerve, and pull it out.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound, if you see it, and take care of that, until it heals up.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of the forceps, with which are extracted arrows.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	May their ends be similar to the face of a wedge, made like an iron; when they grasp onto the arrow, they do not release it.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And there are made from them many species, great and small, and middle ones, according to the quantity of the size of the arrow, and its thinness or thickness, and the constriction thereof.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	This is the form of the impeller.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And this is the form of the impeller of lead.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the end of the lead-shaped impeller as an aid to entry into the hole made in the cone-shaped arrow, and it is driven with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	This end of the lead-shaped impeller cone-shaped is concave as a feather's tip: that it may aid the entry of the arrow into itself and its impulsion.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On phlebotomy of veins.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter LVII.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	Veins that are phlebotomized, those which run through the body, are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of these there are sixteen in the head: two pulsating veins which run behind the ears, called the two herbs; and two arteries, which appear in two places; and two veins which run in the two lacrimal bones of the eyes, called the gazing ones; and a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead; and a vein running in the tip of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two guide-veins which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	These are the veins which are called Algecirach.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	But the veins which are phlebotomized in the arms, there are five veins in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the cephalic, and it comes from the lateral side of the tree: and it is called by the common name of the head vein.
Et Fusca.	Et Fusca.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And the wound is on the left side, and it is in a place where the bone of the skull meets the spine, and it is named because it is in a common area of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the wound is on the right side, and it is in a place where the bone of the skull meets the spine, and it is named because it is in a place that is not common to the body.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And the wound is in the front, and it is in a place where the bone of the wrist meets the bone of the forearm, and it is named because it is in a common area of the body.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the wound is on the front of the arm, and it is on a vein that is near the elbow, and it is one where blood is withdrawn, and it is one where the flexor tendon of the thumb appears to be thin.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the wound is on the back of the hand, and it is between the ring finger and the little finger, and there are two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	In the leg and in the foot there are three wounds.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is that which is under the thumb, from a forest side.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	The second is the saphenous vein, and its location is near the heel, on the inside leg.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the third is the nerve, and its location is near the heel, on the outside leg.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And there are three similar wounds in the other leg.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	This text describes the location of wounds on the body, with particular attention to the veins and nerves that might be involved in the injury. It appears to be an anatomical description related to medical treatment or dissection.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The phlebotomy of the two veins that are behind the ears is important for treating several conditions: scurvy, hemorrhoids, swelling, and bad ulcers on the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the phlebotomy should be according to what is said in this text.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is, so that the head heals well: and it rubs the back of the neck between two veins with a rough cloth for good friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then tie the injured neck tightly with a scarf, until the two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their locations are behind the ears in two depressed areas of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	So then feel with your finger, and where you feel the pulse of the veins under your finger, there are the marks with cauterization.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take up the scalpel, and he is called the 'Incise'.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then introduce it into the wound, until the phlebotomist reaches the mouth.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then wash your hand with water and the skin at the top, and incise the wound with the incision knife.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And make the length of the incision as much as two fingers spread out, or about that: and allow to flow out as much blood as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then tie it up with thread, and let it be, until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And already preceded in the beginning of this book with the incision of ears, and their cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	Of the phlebotomy of the two arteries in the temples.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	But the two arteries which are in the two temples that are phlebotomized, are for the ancient hemianopsia: and the socket of the ball's eye, and the constant obturating. And the course of the flowing acuter all around the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of phlebotomy is according to what I tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The sick man shall strain his neck very much, until two veins appear with a visible pulsation under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then the signs are with the caustics.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then wash the skin above the vein from above with your index finger, and introduce the phlebotomist underneath, and wash the veins from above.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And incise it, as you did in the two other veins: and allow to flow out of blood according to the quantity of your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then remove the tourniquet and place your finger on one vein for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then put over it a cotton and the thread, and squeeze it strongly with your hand: and let it be, until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And already preceded with the memory of ears, and their incision, and their extraction at the beginning of this book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	Of the phlebotomy of the frontal vein after the phlebotomy of the head.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The true treatment of bleeding from the nose is after phlebotomy of the head, to treat old ailments of the face: and for hemicrania, and redness: and foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of phlebotomy, I will tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The injured man raises his neck with a cough until the blood appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument called a fossorum.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is its shape:
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the prominent point that is in the head of the fossorum on top of the blood, and strike it with a comb or some other way: and let the blood flow according to the amount you want.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then solve the perforation with a poultice, and tighten it, until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And when it opens again with the phlebotomist on the side.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it is not necessary that there be a phlebotomist at the acute end, as with the other phlebotomies, so it is with the lateral ends.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And bleed her according to the turn: for the mouth is close by: and perhaps, when it is thin, the phlebotomizes may break when it is slender.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	Regarding the phlebotomy of veins in two tearful eyes.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The treatment of two veins that are in the two tearful eyes of the two eyes, is for the eye from scabies and redness: and for a sore in the eye, and facial ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of phlebotomy of them, so that the injured man raises his neck with a cough until the blood appears.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then bleed her: and you stand over its head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let the phlebotomy be according to the turn a little bit in length, with a little phlebotomist, a little on the side, for there is no flesh in place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If then the phlebotomizes is slender at the end, perhaps it will break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let the blood flow according to the amount you need.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And place on them a poultice, and tighten them at night, and solve them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	Phlebotomy of the nasopharyngeal veins.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The phlebotomy of the nasopharyngeal veins is useful for acute fever, violent thirst, facial illnesses such as hemicrania and redness that occurs on the face; especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that it should squeeze the neck of the sick person.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then take the nose of him with your left hand, and take a fine, long phlebotomy; and fasten it in the middle of his nose, between that which separates the nose according to its straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Since the vein does not appear to the touch there, and because blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And you should hold the last phlebotomy a little longer: and let the blood flow according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind it for the night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For it will heal very quickly itself.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	Phlebotomy of the jugular veins.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	Indeed, the two jugular veins are useful for constriction of the throat, the beginning of leprosy, melancholy illnesses, impetigo and bad ulcers, and for corrosion, that is, scabs from scabies.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that the sick person should be tied with a ligature on each side of his neck: and let the artisan stand over his head, and let the sick person sit on a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then take a phlebotomy according to the length of the wide phlebotomy a little more.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then draw out a temperate quantity of blood, or according to what you see from necessity, which is to that.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do the same for the other nose.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then loosen the ligatures, and tighten two veins in the middle: so that the sick person does not become constricted.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let it go until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	For the wound will heal itself.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	Phlebotomy of the algerich veins.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	And Al-Ghabri's phlebotomy tool is an aid: for it is placed at the lip of the mouth, and brings about corruption of the gums: and bad ulcers: and chaps of the lips, and also bad ulcers, even those that are in the nose, and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of phlebotomy is such, that you should make the sick person sit before you: and tighten his neck with a scarf.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then turn the lips of him and look at two veins: one is on the right side of the mouth, and the second is on the left side: and the indication of each is by the color of amber.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And this is true: for there are small veins around them, black.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	So cut both incisions where you want to.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	But if there is doubt about them on you, and you do not know which are they: then you should go to the greater incision of them, and more evident.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And likewise do with the two veins that are in the upper lip: and indeed there is much use to go with it: and cut two veins that are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	Regarding phlebotomy Under the tongue, after phlebotomy of the head.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	And the two veins that are under the tongue, is an aid, for it is phlebotomy of the head, to remove the phlegm that is in the throat, and disease of the throat, and disease of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of phlebotomizing them is such, that the sick person sits between your hands to the sun: and make him drink water, and look at the veins on one side of his tongue, and on the other side of his tongue: and show the color of each to the color of amber.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	So phlebotomize both: and guard, so that you do not put your hand into their veins after phlebotomy.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under them are the arteries, and perhaps it happens that a flow of blood comes out from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Regarding three veins on the chest.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	But the veins which are phlebotomised in the thigh, are those in which phlebotomy was customary in all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And phlebotomy is done on them according to two methods.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Or by puncturing with the phlebotome on one side: or by oiling to the sensitivity of the decline: or by cutting with the phlebotome with an awl, and it is Anelesius.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is his form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Anelesius is, which is suitable for the section.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from them are species broad, and according to the width of their veins and their form the phlebotomy with the awl is broad, like you see it.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is suitable for opening closed veins, full, returning, visible, thick, and those which contain thick blood, turbulent.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this phlebotomist is smaller in width, and more delicate at the extremities.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is suitable for phlebotomy of thin veins, which contain citrinin blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	¶ Of the Basilica phlebotomy.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	But the Basilica, which is one of the three veins phlebotomised, is the iuuamentum.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	For it draws blood from the diseases which are under the throat and the neck, because it follows the chest and the abdomen: and it is suitable for the phlebotomist to cut it with the phlebotome, in order that he may beware, and be on his guard, for under it is an artery.
