Si ergo frangitur, tunc restauratio eius est secundum unum duorum modorum.	If it is broken, then its restoration is according to two ways.
Quorum unus est: ut accipias lignum planum mediae grossitudinis, secundum hanc formam, quae sequitur.	Of which one is: that you take a flat piece of wood of middle thickness, according to this form, which follows.
Et ligentur in duabus extremitatibus duo ligamenta.	And bind two ligaments at both ends.
Deinde suspendatur ex loco eleuato: et sedeat infirmus super sedem.	Then let it hang from a elevated place: and let the sick person sit on a seat.
Deinde proiiciat brachium suum fractum super lignum, donec perueniat ad titillicum eius, in cuius medio sit annexa curuitas ligni.	Then let him put his broken arm on the wood, until it reaches its tip, in which middle there is attached a little piece of wood.
Deinde suspende desuper ipsum aliquid graue, ut extendat ipsum minister ad inferiora.	Then hang it from above the person with something heavy, so that he extends his hand down towards the ground.
Deinde aequet medicus fracturam manibus suis simul, donec redeat fractura, secundum quod oportet.	Then the physician shall set the fracture of his own hands at once, until the fracture is healed, as it ought to be.
Et modus alter est, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et suspende manum eius a collo ipsius cum ligamento.	And another method is that he should lie down on his own chest: and he shall hang his hand from his neck with a sling.
Deinde praecipe duobus ministris, ut teneat unus eorum illud quod est supra fracturam cum manibus suis: et ut alter teneat inferius eius, et extendat unusquisque eorum ad partem suam.	Then command two servants, that they should hold on either side of his hand that is above the fracture: and that each one of them should hold down the other, and each one of them should stretch out his hand to his side.
Et si uis, ut sit extensio fortior, tunc stringe sub fractura cum ligamento, et supra ipsam cum ligamento alio: et extendat ea unusquisque duorum ministrorum ad duas partes suas.	And if you wish that the extension be stronger, then bind under the fracture with a bandage, and over it with another bandage: and each one of the two servants shall stretch out his hand to his side.
Si ergo fractura est propinqua extremitati humeri, tunc oportet, ut ponatur unum ligamentum sub titillico, et alterum sub fractura uersus cubitum.	If then the fracture is near the end of the arm, then it is necessary that there should be placed one bandage under the elbow joint, and another under the fracture towards the hip.
Et similiter si fractura est propinqua cubito: tunc oportet, ut ponatur ligamentum super illum locum, et super cubitum ipsum.	And in the same way, if the fracture is near the hip: then it is necessary that there should be placed a bandage on that spot, and above the hip itself.
Deinde aequa fracturam cum facilitate absque labore, donec quando aequatur fractura secundum quod oportet, et applicatur applicatione bona: tunc stringe eam, si non accidit apostema calidum.	Then set the fracture with ease without working, until it is levelled as it ought to be, and applied with a good application: then bind it, if there does not occur a swelling that is hot.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam usque ad diem septimum.	But if a swelling that is hot does occur, then release the binding until the seventh day.
Et pone super ipsum lanam succidam imbibitam in aceto et oleo rosato, donec quando quiescit apostema: tunc stringe eam: et modus stringendi eam est, ut ponas emplastrum super fracturam.	And put on the body a woolen cloth dipped in vinegar and olive oil until it is calm the swelling: then bind it: and the way of binding it is, that you should place an ointment over the fracture.
Deinde pone inuolutionem ex panno nouo super emplastrum.	Then put on a new solution from a cloth above the ointment.
Deinde aggreget brachium super adiutorium ipsum, et ponat manum suam apertam super humerum suum.	Then he shall set his arm on his aid, and place his hand open on his shoulder.
Et pone pannum, et stringe super adiutorium brachium, ut brachium stet loco astellarum: si non prohibet te ab illo aliquid, neque alteretur super te aliquid ex osse fracto.	And put on a cloth, and bind over the aid arm, so that the arm stands in its place by means of the stars: if he does not forbid you from doing this, or anything else, or does not change your mind about it, do not do it to him from any broken bone.
Quod si times, quod alteretur super te ex osse fracto aliquid, tunc utere astellis: et est, ut ponas super fracturam ipsam astellam quae sit latior et fortior reliquis astellis.	If it is time, and something changes within you from a broken bone, then use the stars: and it is, that you place over the fracture the star which is wider and stronger than the rest of the stars.
Et ponas inter omnem astellam latitudinem digiti: et sit longitudo astellarum secundum fracturam cum additione trium digitorum ab omni parte.	And place between all the stars the width of a finger: and let the length of the stars be according to the fracture with the addition of three fingers from every side.
Deinde stringe super astellas strictura quam dixi in principio capituli.	Then tighten over the stars the tightness which I said at the beginning of the chapter.
Et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae strictior.	And let your tightness be over the place of the fracture tighter.
Et quanto plus elongatur fractura, sit strictura minor.	And as much as the fracture lengthens, let the tightness be smaller.
Si ergo uides situm astellarum et stricturam, sicut diximus, in hora qua restauras membrum statim, tunc fac: et si times apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam et astellas usque ad diem septimum, sicut diximus.	If then you see the setting of the stars and the tightness, as we have said, in the hour when you restore the limb immediately, then do it: and if it is time for a poultice of heat, then leave the tightness and the stars until the seventh day, as we have said.
Deinde considera ligamentum in omnibus tribus diebus, ut non accidat in loco pruritus, aut inflatio, aut prohibeatur cibus peruenire ad membrum, propter dispositionem superfluitatis stricturae.	Then consider the ligaments in all three days, that no itchiness may occur in the place, or swelling, or hinderance of food reaching the limb, because of the fluidity of tightness.
Rectifica ergo illud totum, secundum quod diximus.	Correct then that whole thing, according to what we have said.
Si uero es super fiduciam, ut non accidat ex illo aliquid: tunc non soluas ligamentum, nisi post tres dies, aut plus.	If however you are on trust, so that nothing may come from it: then do not loosen the ligaments, unless after three days, or more.
Et sit dormitio infirmi super dorsum suum, et manus eius super stomachum suum: et pone sub adiutorio culcitram plenam lana aequaliter.	And let him lie on his back on his pillow, and his hands on his belly: and let you place under the bed a full woolen sheet equally.
Et considera in omni hora noctis, aut diei, ut non soluatur figura membri fracta, aut mollificetur ligamentum.	And consider at every hour of night or day, that the figure of the broken member may not be loosened, nor the ligaments softened.
Rectifica ergo illud totum uirtute tua.	Correct then that whole thing by your virtue.
Et pone cibum infirmi secundum ordinem quem praemisimus, ita ut sit cibus subtilis in primis, donec incipiat os stringi: tunc oportet, ut ingrosses cibum eius.	And place for the nurse food according to the order which we have set forth, so that there is a slight food at first, until it begins to tighten his jaw: then let there be increased for him the food.
De consuetudine enim adiutorii et cruris est, ut stringatur in quadraginta diebus: tunc ergo oportet, ut soluatur, et administretur balneum, et medicetur cum unguentis quae rectificant illud.	For the custom of aid and of the limb is, that it be tightened in forty days: then therefore let it be loosened, and administered a bath, and be treated with an ointment which corrects it.
Quod si fractura fuerit foeda, attrita: tunc non soluas ab ea ligamentum et astellas usque ad quinquaginta dies, et usque ad duos menses.	If the fracture is bad and bruised, then do not separate from it the ligaments and stars until fifty days, and until two months.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Brachii.	De restoratione fracturait brachiae:
Caput XIII.	[III] If the fracture is of the upper arm:
Brachium est compositum ex duobus ossibus, quae nominantur duo focilia.	The forearm is composed of two bones which are called two phalanges.
Quorum unum est paruum: et est illud quod sequitur pollicem.	Of which one is small: and it is that which follows the thumb.
Et alterum est magnum, et est illud quod est positum sub paruo ab inferiori parte.	And the other is large, and it is that which is placed under the little finger on the lower part.
Fortasse ergo frangitur focile maius solum, aut paruum: et fortasse franguntur simul.	Maybe therefore breaks only one phalange, or the other, or maybe both at the same time.
Quando ergo frangitur focile paruum superius, tunc restauratio eius est facilis, et sanatio eius est facilior.	When therefore a phalange is broken which is small and upper, then the restoration of it is easy, and the healing of it is easier.
Et quando frangitur focile inferius, est fractura eius mala, et sanatio eius difficilis.	And when a phalange is broken which is lower, this is a bad fracture, and the healing of it is difficult.
Et deterior ea est, quando franguntur duo ossa simul.	And worse is it when both bones break at the same time.
Si ergo os quod frangitur est focile parum superius, tunc conuenit medico apud restaurationem eius, ut ponat extensionem paruam cum facilitate, donec aequet ipsum.	Now if the bone which is broken is a small phalange upper, then it is fitting for the physician to come to its restoration, in order that he may place an extension which is small with ease, until it is equal.
Si uero focile magnum est illud quod fractum est: tunc oportet, ut ponat stricturam fortiorem ualde.	But if the phalange which is broken is large: then it is necessary, so that he may place a strong one which is tight.
Et oportet, ut ponat figuram manus apud restaurationem eius, et ipsius extensionem extensam super puluinar.	And it is necessary, so that he places the shape of the hand at its restoration, and an extension beyond the knuckle on the little finger.
Et sit pollex manus ad superiora altior omnibus digitis: et sit articularis inferior omnibus digitis, uel reliquis: et infirmus sedens quadratus super seipsum, et sit puluinar coram eo, uel in directo eius, in altitudine, ut non incurrat infirmus laborem.	And let the thumb of the hand be placed higher on all the fingers: and let the flexor be placed on all the fingers, or other: and let it be sitting square on itself, and let the little finger face it, or in its direction, in height, so that it does not incur pain.
Deinde extendat minister Brachium ab inferiori parte, aut manu sua, aut cum ligamento.	Then he should extend the arm from the lower part, or with his own hand, or with a ligature.
Et minister alius extendat desuper similiter.	And another minister should extend from above.
Deinde aequet medicus os, donec reducat ipsum secundum meliorem figuram quam potest.	Then the physician should set the bone, until he reduces it according to the best shape that he can.
Quod si in fractura ossis sunt satagiae, tunc conare reducere omne frustum in loco suo uirtute tua.	If there are fractures of the bones, then consider reducing all the fragments to their places with your power.
Si uero apparet in eo sathaiatum separatum, et pungit cutem, et non est tibi spes in restauratione eius: tunc finde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum secundum modum quem diximus in eis quae praemissa sunt.	If there is indeed a separate satthaiatum [a type of fracture] and you prick the skin and do not expect to restore it: then find over it, and remove it according to the manner that we have said in those that precede this one.
Si autem fractura est cum uulnere, ego iam feci ad illud capitulum singulare, ergo accipe curationem illius inde.	But if the fracture is with a wound, I have already done for that singular chapter, so take the cure of it from there.
Quod si accidat in principio tuae restaurationis apostema calidum, tunc line pannum cum caeroto facto ex oleo rosato, et caera alba, et sit medium inter spissitudinem et subtilitatem: et stringe pannum super ipsum strictura subtili, donec quando sedatur apostema: tunc remoue caerotum, et pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum albumine oui.	If it happens in the beginning of your cure [of the wound] that the apostema is hot, then take a thin cloth made of linen with a blue dye, and white wax, and place between its thickness and thinness: and bind the cloth tightly over it, until when the apostema sits down: then remove the waxy [ cloth], and put a prepared plaster made from ground flour with albumen.
Deinde pone astellas, et sit astella quae ponitur super fracturam ipsam latior parumper, et fortior.	Then put on plasters, and let the plaster that is placed on the fracture be slightly wider, and stronger.
Et scias, quod numerus astellarum Brachii est sex in pluribus dispositionibus: siue sit fractura in focili uno, aut in duobus focilibus simul.	And you should know that the number of plasters of the arm is six in many dispositions: whether it is a fracture in one  [bone] or two  [bones] simultaneously.
Deinde pone stricturam tuam super locum fracturae fortiorem et uehementiorem, et aliquanto plus cum strictura ad superiora fracturae, aut ad inferiora eius: aut pone stricturam molliorem strictura eius parumper, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius in principio capituli.	Then put on your binding tighter and more robust over the site of the fracture, and somewhat more with the binding towards the upper part of the fracture, or towards the lower part: or put on a softer binding over it according to what preceded it at the beginning of the chapter.
Et sint panni qui inuoluuntur super fracturam, panni lenes, humidi: et non sint duri, asperi.	And let the cloths that are wrapped over the fracture be soft, damp cloths: and not hard, rough.
Et sit filum quo stringitur ex lino proprie, medium inter subtile et grossum, sicut narrauimus.	And let there be a thread that is tied with linen itself, between thinness and thickness, as we have said.
Et considera membrum et ligamentum post dies.	Consider the limb and its ligaments after a few days.
Quod si accidat aliquid cuius rectificatio sit necessaria, sicut pruritus qui accidit membro: tunc oportet, ut embroces membrum cum aqua calefacta, donec quiescat ille pruritus, et dimittas membrum non constrictum, donec quiescat, deinde itera stricturam.	If something happens that requires correction, such as a itch that occurs in the limb: then it should be, let the member soak in hot water, until that itch subsides, and remove the member without constricting, until it subsides, and then repeat the binding.
Quod si strictura iam mollificata est, et os iam remotum, et similia illis: tunc rectifica illud totum uirtute tua, et considera iterum.	If the stricture has already been softened, and the bone has already been removed, and similar things: then rectify all of it with your power, and consider again.
Nam si nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad membrum, propter superfluitatem stricturae, tunc oportet, ut mollifices ipsum parumper, et dimittas ipsum aliquot diebus, donec currat ad ipsum nutrimentum, deinde stringe ipsum.	For if nourishment is prevented from reaching the limb by an excess of stricture, then it is necessary that you make it a little softer and leave it for several days, until it heals up, and then tighten it again.
Si autem non accidit infirmo aliquid eorum quae diximus, tunc non oportet, ut soluatur, nisi post uiginti dies, aut circiter hos.	But if any of these things do not happen to the sick person that I have said, then it is not necessary that he should be made well, except after twenty days or about that number.
Deinde suspendatur manus infirmi ad collum eius.	Then hang up his hand so as to support his neck.
Et sit collum eius aequale, et custodiatur uirtute sua a motibus agitatiuis.	And let his neck be kept even, and guarded from violent movements with your power.
Et fac eum dormire super dorsum suum.	And make him lie on his back.
Et scias, quod haec fractura in triginta diebus, aut in triginta duobus diebus restauratur: et fortasse restauratur in uigintiocto diebus.	And you should know that this fracture is restored in thirty days, or in thirty-two days; and perhaps it is restored in twenty-eight days.
Totum illud est secundum dispositiones complexionum, et dispositiones uirtutis.	All of this depends on the condition of the flesh, and the power that you have.
¶ De restauratione fracturarum Manus.	On the restoration of fractures of the hand.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XXII.
Scias, quod pectini Manus, et nodis digitorum raro accidit fractura.	You should know that it is rare for a fracture to occur in the palm of the hand or in the knuckles of the fingers.
Et non accidit ei, nisi attritio multotiens.	And it does not happen to him unless he has a great deal of grinding.
Quando ergo accidit plantae fractura, aut attritio: tunc oportet, ut sedeat infirmus quadratus: et coram eo sit sedes secundum aequalitatem.	When therefore a fracture occurs, or grinding: then it is necessary that the sick person should lie on his back: and before him they should set up a second seat, equal to the first.
Deinde pone Manum eius super eam extensam.	Then put his hand on top of it.
Deinde extendat minister ossa fracta, et aequet ea medicus, donec quando coniunguntur coniunctione bona.	And then make the bones that are broken to meet, and equal them with the power of the doctor, until they are joined together by a good union.
Tunc oportet, ut ponat emplastrum et stuppam, si non accidat apostema calidum.	Then it is necessary that he should put on a plaster and a splint, if a swelling does not occur.
Deinde pone astellam desuper secundum quantitatem loci: et tu iam inuoluisti eam in panno lini.	Then put the splint from above, according to the amount of space: and you have already wrapped it in linen cloth.
Si autem fractura est ad inferiora circiter uentrem plantae, tunc fac simile spherae ex panno: et praecipe infirmo, ut coartet super eam cum planta sua fracta: deinde stringatur cum panno longo.	But if the fracture is lower down round about the wrist of the hand, then make a sphere-like shape out of cloth: and order the sick person to wrap his hand with it so as to support it with his own hand that is broken: and then tighten it with the long cloth.
Et sit astella ex corio, in quo sit lenitas, ut applicetur corium cum corpore plantae: et stringe eam, secundum quod oportet.	And put it on a branch of cork, where it is soft, so that it can be applied to the plant's body; and bind it, according to what is needed.
Si autem fractura est ad exteriora, tunc oportet: ut ponas astellam desuper, et astellam aliam ab inferiori in planta: et sit manus aperta recta.	But if the fracture is on the outside, then it should be like this: you should put one branch above and another below the plant; and hold your hand flat.
Deinde pone stricturam, sicut reuoluitur manus: et extende inter digitos cum ligamento.	Then place the splint as if it were a strap: and extend it between the fingers with a bandage.
Quod si accidat fractura alicui nodorum digitorum, tunc si est pollex, aequetur secundum quod oportet.	That if a fracture should occur to any of the fingers' joints, then if it is the thumb, it should be made equal in length as needed.
Deinde stringatur cum planta: et si amas, pone ei astellam rectam, paruam: ut eleuetur fractura, et non moueatur.	Then tie it to the plant: and if you wish, put a straight branch on either side of the fracture so that it does not move and does not bend.
Si autem fractura est reliquis digitis, sicut medio, et indici, aut auriculari, et anulari, tunc aequetur, et ligetur cum digito sano qui sequitur eum: aut ligentur omnes secundum continuationem: et est melius.	But if the fracture is in any of the other fingers, like the middle, or the index, or the ring, or little finger, then it should be made equal and tied to the finger that comes after it: or all of them should be tied together according to their length, and that is better.
Aut pone super ipsum astellam paruam, sicut diximus in pollice.	Or put a branch on top of it as we have said for the thumb.
Et considera in restauratione tua, et post ipsam dispositionem apostematis calidi: et oppone cum eo quod oportet, quando accidit aliquid ex illo, secundum quod iteratur eius narratio.	And consider in your restoration, and after that arrangement, wait with heat: and oppose it to what is needed when something happens to it, according to its story.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Coxae.	On the Restoration of a Hip Fracture:
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
OS Coxae multotiens frangitur, et declaratur sensui: quoniam conuertitur ad interiorem et posteriorem partem.	The hip bone often breaks and is felt: because it turns inward and backward.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, quod stringitur ligamentum supra fracturam, et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	And the restoration of it is such that one ties a ligature above the fracture, and another below it.
Et infirmus prostretur super faciem suam.	And the injured person extends their arm outward on their side.
Deinde extendat omne ligamentum minister ad partem suam secundum aequalitatem: et hoc, quando est fractura in medio ossis.	Then he should extend all the ligaments according to their equality: and this is how it should be done when there is a fracture in the middle of the bone.
Si autem est fractura propinqua radici Coxae, tunc sit ligamentum ad partem pectinis, ut cadat extensio ad sursum: et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	But if the fracture is near the root of the hip bone, then there should be a ligature on one side toward the pelvis so that it does not extend upward; and another below the fracture.
Et sic similiter si est fractura propinqua genu, tunc sit ligamentum propinquum genu, ut sit extensio ad inferiora.	And so likewise if there is a fracture near the knee, then put a bandage around the nearby ligament, so that it extends down to the lower part.
Deinde aequet medicus os utriusque manibus suis, donec reducat ipsum secundum similitudinem figurae naturalis: et coniugatur os coniunctione bona.	Then let the doctor make both of his hands equal in length, until he reduces it according to the natural figure: and let the bones be joined together with a good joint.
Tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum et stricturam, si non accidit membro apostema.	Then it should be put on plaster and tightened if there is no swelling of the member.
Quod si accidat in eo apostema: tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur apostema calidum, deinde redi ad curationem tuam.	What if there is swelling in it: then let him rest for a few days, until the swelling becomes warm, and then return to your cure.
Strictura autem eius ita sit.	But the bandage should be such.
Oportet ut inuoluas super fracturam imema duram, id est, bindam: et dupla eam bis, aut ter: et remaneat ex ea superfluitas.	It is necessary that you wrap a piece of cloth tightly over the fracture, that is, a bandage: and double it twice, or three times: and let there remain from it an excess.
Deinde inuolue crus, donec perueniat calcaneus apud radicem natis.	Then wrap the leg, until it has reached the root of the foot.
Et intromitte filum longum inter Coxam et crus prope genu ad inferiora, et ueniant extremitates fili a superiori parte duarum partium.	And insert a long thread between the thigh and the leg close to the knee towards the lower part, and let the ends of the thread come from the upper side of the two parts.
Deinde reuolue super Crus et Coxam quod superfluit ex alimema.	Then wrap the leg and thigh, what remains of the cloth.
Deinde pone super Coxam in loco fracturae ipsius astellas, et pone ex eis astellam unam super os cruris.	Then put on the thigh in the place of the fracture as many stars as are necessary: and let there be one star placed over the bone of the leg.
Deinde imple uacuitates inter crus et coxam cum pannis lenibus, ut aequetur strictura.	Then fill with plasters between the leg and the thigh, soft ones, so that the bandage is even.
Deinde incipe cum strictura forti a medio super locum fracturae tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor.	Then begin with the strong bandage from the middle of the place of the fracture, three turns, or four.
Et quanto plus elongaris cum ligamento a loco fracturae, sit strictura tua minor et mollior, et lenior.	And the longer the ligament extends from the place of the fracture, the smaller and softer should be your bandage, and the softer it is.
Deinde intende ad duas extremitates fili, quod tu intromisisti inter coxam et crus.	Then bring to the ends of the thread, which you have inserted between the thigh and the leg.
Liga ergo cum utrisque tres astellas quae sunt desuper.	Bind then with the three stars that are above.
Deinde uade cum duabus extremitatibus fili ad inferiora, donec peruenias ad cauillam pedis.	Then bring to the lower ends of the thread, until you have reached the heel of the foot.
Et cum utrisque stringe etiam extremitates astellarum a parte altera: ut non remoueatur ligamentum ex loco suo.	And tie also the ends of the stars from the other side: so that the bandage does not move away from its place.
Deinde dimitte stricturam super illud, dum permanet, ita quod non accidat membro corrosio, neque apostema, neque inflatio, et similia eis.	Then let go of the ligature on this, while it remains, so that corruption does not occur to the member, nor aposteme, nor swelling, and such like to them.
Quod si accidat aliquid ex illo.	That if anything should happen from that.
Propera ergo cum solutione eius, et rectifica illud quod accidit inde totum, secundum quod diximus multotiens.	Then with the solution of that, and rectify what has happened there all together, according to what we have said many times.
Si uero in osse est frustum ex osse quod pungat: tunc oportet, ut aeques illud, si est tibi possibile.	But if a fragment of bone pokes you: then it should be fixed by you, if it is possible to do so.
Et si non, finde super illud, et remoue illud: et cura cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio, donec sanetur.	And if not, find on top of it, and move that one: and take care with it who remembers it before, until it heals.
Et quandoque stringitur haec fractura Coxae, praeter quod addantur ei astellae, sicut diximus in adiutorio et brachio.	And when this fracture of the hip is tight, except that stars are added to it, as we have said in the thigh and arm.
Verumtamen in restauratione eius taliter fracta, non accidit infirmo claudicatio.	However, in restoring it, so that the fracture does not cause a limp.
Et si restauratur sola, praeter quod applicetur ei crus alterum, tunc necesse est, ut claudicet ille cuius est, semper.	And if it is restored by itself, except that the other leg is applied to it, then it is necessary that he who has it should always limp.
Et scias, quod Coxa stringitur in quinquaginta diebus, uel additur parum, aut minuitur parum: totum illud est secundum diuersitatem complexionum, et reliquarum dispositionum.	And know that the hip is tight after fifty days, or that a little is added to it, or a little is relaxed: all of this is according to the difference of coloration, and the rest of dispositions.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Rotulae genu.	Regarding the restoration of the fracture of the rotula of the knee.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod Rotulae genu raro accidit fractura, sed accidit ei attritio multotiens.	You should know that the fracture of the rotula of the knee rarely happens, but it often happens to him.
Si uero accidit ei fractura, tunc non nisi aut fissura, aut foramen in partibus suis.	But if it has happened to him a fracture, then there is only one thing: either a crack, or a hole in its parts.
Et est illud cum uulnere, et absque uulnere.	And this is with injury, and without injury.
Et statur super illud totum cum sensu.	And stand on top of it all with a sense.
Et restauratio eius est ita, ut aequetur quod disruptum est ex partibus eius cum digitis, donec aggregetur, et coniungatur secundum quod possibile est ex aequatione et facilitate, et fabricatione.	And the restoration of it is such that it equitates what has been disrupted from its parts with the fingers, until it gathers together, and joins according to what is possible from the correction and ease, and manufacture.
Deinde pone emplastrum ex farina sisami, uel molendini, cum albumine oui: et pone super ipsum astellam rotundam, si indiges illa: et stringe desuper strictura conueniente ad illud.	Then put a plaster of rice flour, or of flour, mixed with egg white: and put on top of it an oval star, if you can bear it: and tighten tightly with a fitting bandage to it.
Deinde considera omnes dispositiones quas narrauimus in reliquis fracturis: sicut apostema calidum, et similia illi: ita, ut opponas omni accidenti cum eo quod conuenit ei, donec sanetur.	Then consider all the dispositions which we have mentioned in the rest of the breaks: such as ecstasmes of heat and similar things to them: so that you oppose every accident with what is suitable for it, until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Cruris.	§ On restoring a broken leg.
Caput XVII.	Ch. XX.
Scias, quod Cruri sunt duo ossa, quorum unum est grossum, et nominatur nomine Cruris: et alterum subtile, et nominatur Focile.	You should know that there are two bones of the leg, one is thick and called by the name of the leg; and the other is fine, and called by the name of the femur.
Et accidit utrisque ex speciebus fracturae quod accidit duobus ossibus brachii: et propter illud fit restauratio eius, sicut restauratio brachii aequaliter, et operatio est una.	And it happens to both bones of the leg, in the same species of fracture which happens to the two bones of the arm; and because of this, its restoration is done as with the restoration of the arm equally, and the operation is one.
Quod si franguntur duo ossa simul, conuertitur Crus ad omnes partes.	Which if both bones break at the same time, the leg becomes dislocated in all parts.
Et si frangitur os subtilius, conuertitur Crus ad anteriorem partem.	And if the fine bone breaks, the leg is dislocated towards the front.
Et si frangitur os grossius, inuenis illud inferius: et est ex eis quae non occultantur tibi.	And if the thick bone breaks, it dislocates downward; and of these two which do not conceal themselves from you.
Deinde administra extensionem, et aequationem, et ligationem astellarum secundum illud aequaliter.	Then administer extension, and equality, and binding of the astrags according to that as equal.
Verumtamen oportet, si fractura Cruris est fractura foeda, habens sethagie multa: ut sit extensio minor, et lenior alleuiatione tua.	However, if the fracture of the leg is a bad fracture, it has many complications: so that it is necessary to make an extension less and with milder alleviation for you.
Et in Crure quidem est ex operatione quiddam super brachium: et est, ut quando tu aequas astellas, et comples omnem operationem tuam, tunc accipe duas fascias ex ligno pini, quod administratur in fabricatione solariorum quod ponitur sub tabulis: et fiunt ex spatulis palmae: et elige ex eis quibus est grossitudo parua, et neque sint ex minutis: et sit longitudo earum secundum longitudinem Cruris a genu usque inferius.	And in the leg itself there is an operation somewhat like that of the arm; and it is, as when you equalize the astrags and complete all your operation, then take two strips from pine wood, which is used in making shoulder joints which are placed under tablets: and they are made from palm leaves: and choose from them those which have a small thickness, and there should not be any of the minute ones: and let their length be according to the length of the leg from the knee down.
Deinde inuolue super unamquamque pannum duabus inuolutionibus secundum longitudinem eius.	Then wrap it up with two pieces of cloth, according to its length.
Et pone unam partem Cruris a parte una, et alteram a parte altera: et sint ex genu usque inferius pedis.	And put one side of the leg from one side, and the other from the other: and let them be from the knee down to the foot.
Deinde liga duas fascias in tribus locis ex duabus extremitatibus et medio.	Then bind two fasci [i.e., strips of tissue] in three places from the two extremities and middle.
Cum enim strictura prohibetur, Crus declinat ad dextram et sinistram, et stat statione bona.	Since constriction is prevented, the incision turns toward the right and left, and remains in good position.
Et iam quidem administretur cunabulum ex ligno secundum longitudinem Cruris, et ponatur in eo Crus, ut conseruet ipsum a motu.	And already a hook is placed from wood according to the length of the crurus [i.e., limb], and placed therein so that it preserve itself from movement.
Et plurimum quidem oportet, ut facias illud in fractura quando cum ea est uulnus proprie.	And much more should you do, so that you make it [i.e., the fracture] when it is a proper ulna.
Deinde considera Crus in omni die, et stude cum eo studio ultimo ab apostemate, aut inflatione, aut reliquis aliis.	Then examine the crus every day, and with great care examine it at the end of apoplexy, or inflammation, or other things.
Si ergo accidit aliquid ex illis, tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur, si Deus uoluerit.	If then anything happens from among these  [i.e., the injuries], then oppose it with what is necessary until it is healed, if God wills it.
De fractura ossium Pedis, et Digitorum.	Of the fracture of bones of the foot and fingers.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Calcaneo quidem non accidit fractura penitus.	The heel bone does not have an innermost fracture.
Ossibus uero Pedis accidit quandoque fractura, et Digitis parum etiam accidit fractura: et non accidit eis nisi attritio in pluribus dispositionibus.	But of the bones of the foot there is sometimes a fracture, and of the fingers it also happens that there is a fracture; but it does not happen to them except through wear and tear in many places.
Quod si accidit ossibus Pedis fractura, et uides illa ossa sublimari super se adinuicem, tunc ponat infirmus Pedem suum super terram praeparatam, sicut ambulans.	Which if there is a fracture of the bones of the foot and you see those bones sliding one over another, then put the injured foot on the ground prepared to walk.
Deinde sta tu, et pone Pedem tuum super illud quod eleuatur ex illis ossibus: postea preme, uel calca eam: et aequa ipsam, donec redeat in locis suis.	Then stand you, and place your foot on that which raises itself from among those bones; then press it or trample it, and make it equal, until it returns to its place.
Deinde pone emplastrum, et stuppam desuper: et pone sub uentre Pedis tabulam paruam, cui sint duo capita plana.	Then put a plaster on it, and a bandage from above; and place under the foot a flat board which has two flat heads.
Deinde stringe eam cum Pede strictura decenti, postquam tu inuoluis eam cum pannis, et reliquis quibus indiget.	Then tighten it with a constricting band around the foot while you are walking it with cloth, and with the rest of what it needs.
Cum ergo praetereunt ei tres dies, aut quatuor, tunc solue ligamentum.	But when three or four days have passed, then solve the ligaments.
Nam tu inuenies ossa aequata, siue sint fracta, aut sint dislocata.	For you will find bones that are equal, or if there are fractures, they are displaced.
Operatio ergo in eis est, sicut uides.	Operation therefore is in them, as you see.
Si autem franguntur aliqui digiti, tunc restaura eos, et aequa ipsos secundum quod narraui tibi in restauratione digitorum manus.	But if any of the fingers are broken, then restore them, and make them equal to each other according to what I told you in the restoration of finger of hand.
Deinde pone digito tuo astellam secundum longitudinem digiti, et sit latior eo parumper: deinde pone sub Pede hanc tabulam quam narraui tibi, et stringe eam strictura decenti.	Then put your finger on the nail according to the length of the finger, and make it as wide as that; then place under the foot this plate which I told you, and tighten it by a tight strap.
Si uero quod frangitur ex ossibus est duo, aut tria, aut plus, tunc pone super omnem digitum astellam suae quantitatis, inuolutam in panno lini: et stringe tabulam in inferiori Pedis: et sit stans super unum capitum tabulae extra uentrem Pedis, ut teneat retentione bona.	But if what is broken is of bones two, or three, or more, then put on all fingers their own plates, wrapped in a linen cloth; and tighten the plate in the lower foot: and let it stand on one tip of the table outside the navel of the foot so that it holds fast by good retention.
Et conuenit tibi, ut non obliuiscaris, quin consideres omnia quae dixi tibi in reliquis fracturis ex accidentibus quae diximus: et oppone omni accidenti cum eo quod oportet.	And it is for you that you do not forget, but consider all that I have told you about the other broken by the accidents which we spoke of: and oppose every accident with him that it should.
¶ De fractura Vuluae mulieris, et ossis pectinis, et uirgae uiri.	As for the fracture of the woman's vulva, and of the bones of the chest, and of the man's genitals.
Caput XIX.	The head of chapter XIX.
Quando frangitur Vulua mulieris, tunc fac eam sedere quadratam.	When the woman' vulva is broken, then make her sit square.
Deinde inclina eam ad partem dorsi ipsius parumper, et teneatur retro.	Then lean her back on the side of her spine about the same way, and hold her.
Deinde impleat obstetrix Vuluam eius coto, donec impleat eam: et fiat in Vulua ex eo sicut sphera.	Then fill the woman' vulva with cotton until she is filled: and let it be in the vulva of her like a ball.
Deinde concutiatur mulier, et eleua dorsum eius paulatim.	Then shake the woman, and dry her back slowly.
Illud enim cotum egreditur, donec fiat ante portam Vuluae sicut sphera, et os fractum redit.	For that cotton comes out before the door of the vulva like a ball, and the broken mouth returns.
Deinde pone puluillum super dorsum eius.	Then put a little wool on her back.
Quando ergo uult mingere, remoueat cotum cum facilitate, deinde mingat: et reduc ipsum secundum modum, quo intromisisti ipsum in primis: deinde redeat ad puluillum suum primum.	But when she wants to urinate, let the cotton move with ease, and then urinate; and reduce it according to the way that you put it in first: and then bring back to her wool first.
Faciat illud septem diebus, aut circiter, os ipsum enim restauratur.	Let it do this for seven days, or so, because the mouth is restored itself.
Et si uis, accipe uesicam ouis, et stringe super foramen eius cannulam arundinis, et intromitte uesicam totam in Vuluam eius.	And if you see a wound, take a wisp of straw and bind it to the opening with thread, and push the whole wisp into his vulva.
Deinde suffla in cannulam cum uirtute, donec infletur uesica intra Vuluam, fractura enim redit.	Then blow into the tube with force, until the wound is pushed inside the vulva, for it returns broken.
Deinde impleatur cum coto, et stet aliquot diebus, secundum quod narrauimus, donec sanetur.	Then fill it with poultice, and let it stand for a few days, as we have related, until it heals.
Et quando frangitur os Pectinis uiri, aut mulieris, tunc administra in restauratione eius, et ipsius aequatione illud quod narrauimus in osse Anchae.	And when the pelvis of a man or woman breaks, then administer to its restoration, and that which we have related concerning the pelvis of anchae.
Et non occultatur rectum in his fracturis propinquis, quae parum contingunt, praecipue cui est quiddam studii, uel usus.	And let not the rectum be hidden in those who are close to breaking, for they are few, especially if there is a certain study or usage.
Et intellige librum meum istum multum, quoniam fractura ipsa significat tibi in pluribus dispositionibus uiam rectam in restauratione sui, et strictura sui: intellige ergo.	And understand my book very well, for the fracture itself signifies to you in many dispositions how your rectum should be straightened in its restoration and narrowing: therefore understand.
In Virga autem uiri quando frangitur, accipe guttur anseris: et intromitte uirgam in ipso.	But when the pelvis of a man breaks, take the throat of a goose; and push the penis into it.
Deinde pone super ipsum inuolutionem ex panno, et inuoluatur, et dimittatur tribus diebus, aut circiter eos, et sanabitur, si Deus uoluerit.	Then place on top of it a turning-over cloth, and turn it over; and let it stand for three days or so, and it will heal, if God wills.
¶ De restauratione fracturae ossium, quando est cum uulnere.	Of the restoration of broken bones, when it is with an arrow.
Caput XX.	Chapter XX:
Conuenit ei cui accidit fractura cum uulnere, praecipue si est magnum, sicut os coxae, aut adiutorii, aut simile illi, ut properes, et phlebotomes ipsum statim: si attestantur tibi conditiones phlebotomiae, sicut praemisimus.	It is appropriate to him who has the fracture with an arrow, especially if it is large, such as the pelvis bone, or auxiliary ones, or similar to it; as you see fit, and let the blood flow out: if you witness the conditions of bleeding, such as mentioned above.
Quod si uulnus effluit sanguinem, tunc oportet, ut properes ad abscisionem eius, ita ut puluerizes super ipsum zegi tritum: si non est tibi praesens aliud.	If the arrow spits blood, then you should, as you see fit, cut off its limb, so that it becomes powder on top of the wound: if there is no other available for you.
Deinde incipe restaurare fracturam in illo eodem die: et non postponas illud, si non accidit apostema.	Then begin to restore the fracture in the same day: and do not put off that which must be done, unless there is a swelling.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte restaurationem eius usque ad diem nonum, donec sedetur apostema.	But if a swelling of heat happens, then dismiss its restoration until the ninth day, until it subsides.
Et non appropinques ei in die tertio, et quarto omnino, nam tu faceres ei accidere accidentia mala.	And do not approach him on the third and fourth days at all, for you will cause him to suffer bad accidents.
Si autem os fractum est eminens super cutem detectum: tunc oportet, ut coneris reducere ipsum, et aequare ipsum manibus tuis cum facilitate et extensione parua.	But if the fracture of the jaw is above the detected wound: then you should consider reducing it and making it even with your hands easily and with a small extension.
Si autem non praeparatur extensio eius, et ipsius aequatio manibus tuis: tunc reduc ipsum cum isto instrumento.	But if the extension of it is not prepared, and its equating with your hands: then reduce him with this instrument.
Et est instrumentum quod fit ex ferro, cuius longitudo est quantitas septem digitorum, aut octo: et eius latitudo est secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And this is an instrument made of iron, the length of which is the quantity of seven or eight fingers; and its breadth is according to the quantity of the wound.
Et propter illud necesse est medico, ut accipiat ex eis tria, aut quatuor secundum quantitatem qua indiget ad illud ex curatione in omni specie fracturae.	And for this reason it is necessary for the physician to take from them three or four according to the quantity that he needs for the cure of any kind of fracture.
Et sit rotundum: et sit in eo grossitudo parua, ut non duplicetur apud compressionem super ipsum in hora operationis: et sit acutae extremitatis, cui sit margo in extremitatibus suis.	And let it be round: and let there be a little roughness on it, so that it does not double itself at the compression on the top in the hour of operation: and let there be an acute extremitas, which has a margin in its extremities.
Et sit superius eius ad grossitudinem ex medietate eius usque ad inferiora.	And let it be above its thickness from its median to its inferior.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.
Oportet in Hac Operatione, ut ponatur extremitas eius acuta curuata super extremitatem ossis eminentis: et impelle ipsum cum eo uice una, donec quando redit os et aequatur quadam aequatione.	In this operation, let the acute extremity be curved over the extremity of the prominent bone: and push it with a one-way force until, when the jaw returns, it is equated with a certain equating.
Conare ergo aequare extremitates fracturae adinuicem.	Therefore consider equating the extremities of the fracture opposite to each other.
Quod si extremitates eius fracta est subtilis, et non accipit eam instrumentum accaeptione bona, tunc opotet, ut incidas extremitatem illius ossis, donec instrumentum potestatem habeat eius.	That if the extremities of it are fragile, and does not take it well with the instrument: then you should consider, that you strike the extremity of its bone, until the instrument can get a hold of it.
Si uero non potes reducere eos cum eo quod narrauimus omnino, tunc incide ipsum cum eo quod conuenit ei ex Incisoriis quae diximus: aut serra ipsum cum una serrarum quocunque modo possibile est tibi.	But if you cannot reduce them at all with what we have said before, then strike him with it that belongs to him from the incisorises that we have mentioned: or clamp him with a one-way clamp in any way possible for you.
Deinde rade illud quod remanet in osse ex asperitate et corticibus minutis.	Then rub off what remains on the bone from the roughness and small cortex.
Cum ergo reducitur os, et inuenit infirmus post reductionem eius dolorem uehementem laedentem, tunc scias, quod os non rediit ad locum suum naturalem.	When therefore the jaw is reduced, and finds itself after the reduction a painful and annoying ache: then you should know that the jaw has not returned to its natural place.
Fac ergo illud.	I shall now proceed to explain that.
Nam tu confers infirmo iuuamentum magnum, cum completur restauratio tua quam facis ossi.	For this reason you give a great help to the sick person when your own recovery is completed by mending the bones.
Tunc submerge pannum in uino stiptico, nigro.	Then dip the cloth in a black vinager.
Et proprie si est in aestate.	And especially if it is in summer.
Et non ponas super uulnus caerotum, neque aliquid in quo sit oleum: ut non faciat accidere in ipso putredinem et corruptionem.	And do not place a poultice of burnt eggshells or any other oil on it: so that it does not happen to him putrefaction and decay.
Deinde administra astellas in hora complementi tui a restauratione ossis.	Then give the medicine at the hour of your own recovery from bone mending.
Et dimitte uulnus detectum: ita, ut incidas cum forficibus foramen in inuolutionibus secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And remove the splint: so that you do not fall by the weight of the splint when you cut open the second hole according to the amount of the wound.
Et caue omni cautela, ne stringas uulnus cum fractura.	And take all precautions so that you do not tighten the broken bone.
Multotiens enim fecerunt istud stolidi medici: et fecerunt accidere super infirmos suos aut mortem, aut corrosionem, aut zuchem, id est, saniem.	For often this has been done by dull doctors and has resulted in illness or death for their patients or decay or swelling, that is, putrefaction.
Et sit strictura tua mollis, lenis, diuersa stricturae fracturarum reliquarum.	And make your own fracture soft, gentle, and different from the tightness of broken fractures.
Quod si uulnus est malum, aut est uulnus magnum, et times super ipsum quaedam accidentia mala quae narrauimus, et inuenis dolorem in loco suspensum: tunc non oportet, ut ponas super ipsum astellas.	For if the bone is bad or large and you place a splint on it which gives rise to a bad accident that we have described, and suspends pain in the place: then you should not place a splint on it.
Et fac eis inuolutiones ex pannis duris in loco astellarum, et stringe ipsum cum eis.	And make the wound closures at the site of the splints, and tighten the bone with them.
Cum autem est post diem unum, aut dies duos, et uides uulnus iam incipere, ut in eo generetur pus: tunc aufer desuper ipsum pannum quem posuisti super ipsum cum uino.	When it is a day old or two days old and you see the bone beginning to putrefy so that pus is being generated in it: then remove the cloth which you placed on top of the bone with vinager.
Deinde administra licinia, et unguenta cum quibus de consuetudine nostra est, ut medicemur uulnera: sicut unguentum tetrapharmacon, et similia illi.	Then give a laxative and ointments which we usually use for medication of wounds, such as the four- herb ointment and others like it.
Et conuenit tibi, ut soluas ligamentum.	And so you may loosen the ligaments.
Et considera uulnus in omni die mane et uespere, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	And consider the bone every day from morning to evening until it is healed and cured.
Et oportet, ut praeparetur membrum taliter, ut currat ex eo pus ad inferiora cum facilitate.	And it should be prepared so that pus can flow out of it easily to the lower parts.
Quod si praetereunt uulneri dies multi, et non consolidatur, neque abscinditur pus ab eo: tunc scias, quod illic sunt satagie ossis parua.	If many days have passed by since the wound and it has not healed, nor has the scar tissue formed: then know that there are little bones in that place.
Quare oportet, ut inquiras uulnus cum tenta.	Why you should inquire about a break when it is testing.
Quot uero ex illis alsatagie sunt separata, remoue ea, et extrahe ipsa.	How many of those little bones are separated, remove them, and pull out themselves.
Et quae ex eis sunt non separata, et pungunt membrum, et faciunt accidere dolorem, conare incidere ea, et auferre ea omni modo quo possibile est tibi illud.	And which of those little bones are not separated, and prick the limb, and cause pain, avert that pain, and remove it in any way possible for you that injury.
Quod si accidat uulneri zuchen, aut ekileten, id est, estiomenus, aut species alia corruptionis et putrefactionis: tunc oportet, ut opponas unicuique ex eis cum eo quod conuenit ei ex curatione, cuius praecessit narratio in capitulo suo.	If it happens to a wound to ache, or to swell, that is, is infected, or any other kind of corruption and putrefaction: then you should oppose each of them with what is suitable for him in the cure, whose prececessory narrative is in his chapter.
Et ex eo in quo oportet ut stet sermo meus, et cui facias praesentem mentem tuam quando frangitur os, et eminet super membrum, sicut os coxae, et adiutorii, et similia eis ex membris magnis, est, ut non praesumas attractionem eius, multotiens enim accidit ex illo mors, imo dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat.	And from that in which it is necessary that my speech should remain standing, and which you make present thought to when a bone breaks, and comes out on a limb, such as the hip bone, and auxiliaries, and similar to them from large limbs, i.e., so that you do not suppose attraction of it, for often happens death from that injury, and moreover remove it, until it putrefies.
Fortasse enim cadet per se post uiginti dies, aut triginta.	Perhaps, indeed, it may fall away by itself after twenty days, or thirty.
Tunc ergo cura uulnus, si uidetur tibi: et sinon, dimitte ipsum.	Then, therefore, cure the break, if you have it: and otherwise, remove it.
¶ De curatione Nodationis in uestigio fracturae.	Of the Cure of a Nodule in a Wound in the Leg.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Multoties accidit haec Nodatio in uestigio sanationis fracturae.	This Nodule often occurs in a wound in the leg.
Praecipue, quae est prope iuncturas: et foedatur ex ea figura membri.	Particularly, that which is near joints: and it grows out of that limb's shape.
Et fortasse prohibet membrum ab operatione sua naturali.	And perhaps does not allow the limb to move in its natural manner.
Considera ergo tunc, si nodatio est recens: administra in ea medicinas quae stipticitatem habent, sicut aloe, et olibanum, et myrrha, et sarcocolla, et acacia, et similia eis.	Consider therefore then, if the Nodule is new: administer to it medicines that have a tightening effect, such as aloe, and olive oil, and myrrh, and lead-ore, and acacia, and similar things.
Ita, ut accipias ex istis quasdam, aut omnes eas: et confice eas cum uino stiptico, aut cum albumine oui, aut cum aceto: et pone eas super nodationem in stuppa, et stringe eas super ipsam strictura bona.	So, that you take some of these things, or all of them: and apply them with astringent wine, or white of egg, or vinegar; and place them on the Nodule in a box, and bind them tightly to it.
Et dimitte stricturam, nec soluas eam diebus multis.	And loose the bandage, and don't remove it for many days.
Deinde solue eam, et itera aliam, donec remoueatur nodatio.	Then remove it, and put on another one, until the swelling goes down.
Aut stringe super ipsam laminam plumbi decenter.	Or tighten with a lead strip laid crosswise over it.
Plumbo enim est proprietas remouendi omne quod timetur ex membris.	Lead is indeed the property of removing anything feared from the body.
Si autem nodatio iam in lapidem conuersa est, et stricta est, et festine prouocat necessitas ad auferendum eam: tunc finde super eam ex superiori parte eius, et incide superfluitatem eminentem: aut rade eam cum quibusdam rasoriis, donec remoueatur: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	But if the swelling has already sunk into the stone, and is tight, and necessity urgently calls for its removal: then find on top of it a little bit, and cut off the excess: or cut it off with some knives, until it comes off: and take care of it, until it heals.
¶ De curatione quando restauratur, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, non secundum naturam suam.	Regarding the cure: when it is restored, and the limb remains stiff after that, not in accordance with its natural state.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Quando restauratur fractura ossis, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, debile: tunc non fit illud nisi propter caussas multas.	When the fracture of a bone is restored, and the limb remains stiff after that, it is not for any other reason but many causes.
Quarum una est, multitudo solutionis ligamenti et ligationis eius non secundum quod oportet: aut propter superfluitatem stricturae ligamentorum, donec prohibeatur nutrimentum currere ad membrum: aut propter multitudinem embrocationis superfluae in non sua hora: aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore infirmi, et debilitatem eius.	Of which one cause is, a multitude of ligatures and ties not according to what is proper: or on account of the excess of ointment applied at the wrong time: or because of a lack of blood in the body, and its weakness.
Et curatio illius est, cibare infirmum, et tenerum facere corpus eius, donec multiplicetur sanguis in eo.	And its cure is, to feed the sick, and make its body strong, until the blood increases in it.
Et administra balneum.	And give it a bath.
Et intromitte gaudium et laeticiam super eum.	And introduce joy and gladness to him.
Deinde pone picem super membrum: ut attrahat pix ad ipsum nutrimentum multum.	Then put a blade on the limb: to attract the blade toward it, so that it draws in much food.
Et assiduet embrocationem eius cum aqua tepida, donec currat nutrimentum, et redeat ad figuram suam naturalem.	And give him frequent ointments with warm water, until the nourishment runs, and returns to its natural form.
¶ De curatione ossium fractorum quando restaurantur tortuose.	Regarding the cure of fractured bones when they heal crookedly:
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII.
Quando accidit membro iam restaurato post sanationem eius tortuositas, et eminentia ossi fracto, aut nodatio: et foedatur per illud forma membri, uerumtamen membrum non prohibetur ab operatione sua naturali: tunc non oportet ut recipias sermonem eius, qui existimat, ut frangatur membrum denuo.	When it happens that a limb, which has been restored to its natural form after its fracture and swelling, is yet crooked, or stiff: and if it is fed by the shape of the limb, not, however, preventing it from performing its proper function: then you should not accept its excuse, that it will break again.
Et iam fuerunt multi stolidorum medicorum et restauratorum, qui fecerunt illud in terra nostra.	And there were also many dull doctors and healers who made that in our land.
Et haec quidem operatio est uituperabilis ualde, perducens ad mortem, uel timorem magnum, ut scilicet sit mortalis.	And this operation is indeed terrible and brings about death or great fear, as if it were deadly.
Verum si claudicatio et nodatio sunt recentes: tunc oportet, ut embrocetur cum aqua tepida, in qua decoctae sint herbae mollificantes, sicut folia alteae, et radix eius, et mellilotum, et illis similia.	But if the swelling and trembling have just begun: then it should be steeped in warm water, in which herbs that soften have been decoked, such as the leaves of aloe, and its root, and melilotus, and others like them.
Et fiat ei emplastrum cum emplastro mollificatiuo, sicut dyachilon decenter factum.	And let there be made for it a poultice with a soft poultice, like one made from dandelion roots ground up.
Aut sumatur mucilago radicis alteae, et concutiatur cum adipe gallinae, aut oleo sisamino: et emplastretur cum eo.	Or let mucilage be made from the root of aloe and mixed with chicken fat or oil of sesamum: and let it be applied with it.
Aut sumantur ficus pingues, et terantur cum fimo columbino, et similibus eis quae nominantur ex medicinis diminuentes consolidationem.	Or let pine trees be taken and ground up with columbine grass and other like remedies that are called by name for reducing the consolidations.
Et quandoque soluitur nodatio cum fricatione assidua, antiqua, et leni, quae fit cum manibus humidis.	And when the trembling has abated with persistent stroking, an ancient and gentle rubbing that is done with wet hands.
Et administretur motus membri ad omnem partem in horis omnibus.	And let the movement of the members be administered to all parts at all times.
Si autem tortuositas iam antecessit, et fortis facta est, et conuersa est in lapidem, et prouocata est necessitas ad curatonem eius cum ferro: tunc oportet, ut secetur superius eius, et soluatur continuatio ossis, et incidatur quod superfluit ex nodatione aut osse cum Incisoriis subtilibus: et administretur facilitas in illo cum sollicitudine et studio.	But if the twistedness has already preceded and is strong and has become fixed to a stone, and the need for its treatment with iron has arisen: then it should be cut above where the bone comes out, and that which comes from the twisting or bone with small nicks should be removed: and ease should be given to it with tenderness and care.
¶ De sermone in Dislocatione.	On the Speech on Dislocation.
Caput XXIIII.	Head 24.
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	Dislocation is the exit of certain joints from their place.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	Why does it restrain itself from its own motion, and is it fixed in position, and does it support the figure of the member.
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	And does it give rise to painful disorders and injuries.
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	But when such a dislocation has occurred, then one should hurry to restore it: and should not delay doing so at all.
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	For if it is delayed, the place will become stiff, and perhaps with it there will be a reduction of the dislocation.
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	Therefore it is not necessary that he should shudder, nor be extended at the time of his examination.
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	For he often makes the spasms happen, and causes pain.
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	But when that happens, then you should come to the wound with a needle.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	Then he should be left alone until the swelling subsides.
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	Then the member is to be massaged with warm water and oil.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	Then it is to be reduced with ease.
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And every member is to be treated with its memory in place.
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	I have already ordered the chapters on dislocations, also according to what came before in the fracture, from the upper part of the body to the lower.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	§ On the care of the lower jaw.
Caput XXV.	Head 25.
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	A little dislocated are both jaws unless it is rare.
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	And the dislocation of the jaw is made according to one of two ways.
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	Or they are removed from their places with a small movement, and become slightly softer.
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	Or they are dislocated with an intact and complete dislocation, until they become softer towards the breast, until the salivia runs away with the wound, and he cannot hold it, nor can he close his mouth, and it slips away from his tongue with the word.
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	When however its dislocation is small, then it returns to several positions by itself with a little.
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	But if the dislocation is complete and intact: then it should be administered a reduction quickly, and not tarry: and it is, as if he holds the head of the wound with his hand: and the doctor introduces his thumb of one hand into the root of the dislocation between his jaw, if the dislocation is from one side.
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	Or introduce two thumbs together, if the dislocation is from both sides.
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	And the other fingers of his hand are out, with which he equates it.
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	And order the sick person to clean his jaws and eat properly again.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And a doctor should have an equal mandible, and should press the mandible until he returns to his place.
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	If it is difficult to reduce it, especially if both are involved: then administer sweating with warm water and oil until the reduction becomes easy: and do not delay the reduction of the teeth at all, as we have said.
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	When they have been reduced and made equal, and the jaw has closed, and they have not become swollen: then place a few clean cloths over them, with a wick that has been made from wax: and oil it with rose water.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	Then bind it easily with soft ligaments.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	And let it rest on its back: and let the head be supported between two cloths so that it does not move to the right or left: and do not force it to chew anything: but let it be given a soft diet, until such time as the pain subsides, and the jaw has closed: then let it eat what it wants, and administer it with ease.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	Do not cause any pain during the surgery on his mouth, or difficulty in eating and drinking, or coughing, until such time as the jaw has closed and is healing.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	If the reduction of the two mandibles becomes difficult, when they are dislocated at some time, and do not return to their places: then many times fever and vomiting occur: and perhaps intestinal distension happens, and perhaps pure chole is relieved.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	When you see this then you know that it is a disaster, and many times that person dies within ten days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	On the reduction of a dislocated furcula, and the extreme end of the humerus bone.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	The furcula does not dislocate from the inside due to the continuity with the sternum.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	And it dislocates sometimes toward the outside: and this is felt by touch.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	And its restoration is so that it lies sick on its back, and extends its arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then wrap the place with your palm and wrap it strongly, for she will come back.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Then put a plaster on it, and wool, and tie it up.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	The extremities of the limb that follows the bed, and continue with it, are rarely dislocated unless by rare chance.
Quod s dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	That which is dislocated on some day: then it should be reduced and made equal as we have said, and that you be prepared for.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then put a plaster on it, and wool, and fasten it up.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And prescribe to the sick person to adhere to rest and quietness until he is healed.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And with this same cure the limb of the humerus is reduced when it separates also from its place.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	[De]reduction [of] dislocation [of] the humerus.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	You know that the humerus is dislocated only in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	Of which one is that it is dislocated towards the side of the tickle towards the lower part.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	Second is that it is dislocated towards the side of the chest.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	And perhaps it is dislocated towards the upper part of the humerus: and this is rare.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	And does not dislocate towards the back because of the spatula.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	And does not dislocate to the front due to nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	Indeed most dislocate and exit towards the lower side towards the tickle: especially in those who have thin flesh.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	Since it exits quickly on them, and enters quickly into them.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	But in those who have much flesh, the opposite is true: that is to say, because it exits with difficulty, and enters with difficulty.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And perhaps happens to some men a blow or a fall, and the humerus is dislocated by a hot poultice, and it is thought because of this that he is already dislocated.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	Therefore let this be your experience until you stand on certain ground, and then proceed to his cure.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	And it is known that dislocation occurs when it turns downward toward the elbow: and you distinguish between a dislocated shoulder and a healthy shoulder.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	For you can clearly see the difference between them; and the dislocation of the shoulder turns toward the head of the arm, and near to the spot where it is touched at the tip of the shoulder: and the sick hand cannot bring its fist to its ear, nor move it in all movements.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	And likewise, if it is dislocated toward the chest or upward: then a clear touch is felt, and it does not hide itself.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	And of this kind of dislocation it is easy to make reduction when it is still fresh, or when the boy is sick.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	And its reduction is such that he lifts his own hand upward.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	Then put your fingers under its tip and with strength bring the joint to its place upward: and let him lift his hand and stretch it upward.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	Then let him put it down again, for himself he will quickly recover.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	If however he does not recover by means of what we have said, and many days have passed since the dislocation occurred: then it is necessary that the sick man should bathe in warm water, and be given a soothing ointment, such as if they had made to boil the roots of alba nox, and foenugraeum, and melilotum in water, and be administered.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	Then the sick man shall lie on his back: and let a sphere and wool be placed under its tip, which is equal to the length of the thumb from the joint.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	Then the doctor shall place his heel on the sphere, and with strength shall lift the shoulder, and attract the sick man's hand downward.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	And another shall hold the sick man' head so that it does not move downward: for he will quickly recover.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	And if you wish, reduce it as follows: and it is such that the longer-term sick man stands by the side, and puts his shoulder under the tip of the sick man: and lift the sick man' s tip upward, until he hangs suspended in the air.
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	And another assistant should take the hand of the patient from below his thigh.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	But if the sick person is light: then it should be that with him something else is suspended, so as to support him: for the dislocation immediately returns.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	And it is also reduced in a second way: and this is that it is fitted to the earth a long piece of wood, the head of which is round figure: like a mortar's hand: that not be thick, nor fine.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	Then it is placed under the sick person after the cloth is placed over the head of the wood: and the sick person is standing according to the length of the wood.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then his hand should be extended from the other side, and his body should be extended with strength: for the joint returns to its place with velocity.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	That if it is difficult to reduce him through all that we have said, then use this care: and this is that you take a piece of wood the length of which is the length of two arms, and its width is the width of four fingers, and its thickness is the thickness of two fingers: whose head is round, so that it eases the entrance into the pit, according to this form.
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	Then soft cloths are tied over the round head, so as not to hurt the wood with the sick person.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	Then it is placed under the titillium (palm) of the nurse, so that the hand or arm extends over the wood to the lower part: and the wood is tied to the aid, arm, and extremity of the hand.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	Then it is placed over the step by the width, and the hand is extended from the lower side, and the remainder of the body is suspended from the other side.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	For the joint immediately enters.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	Then when his entrance is completed in any way possible: then it should be that you place under the sphera  (ball) of equal size made of wool.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	Then put on a prepared ball of woolen flour with olive oil, and white wine over the whole shoulder, as it turns upside down.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	Then tighten the stricture under the tip of the finger; and turn back the ligament over the splint; and join his hand to his neck, and let it rest, and do not move his hand for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	And it is necessary that a weak food be given to him until the member is healed; for it is faster to heal it in this way.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	Then after seven or five days, he should be set free with motion.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	If then it is healed and does not become soft, then it is now healed.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	If then the joint is dislocated many times, because of the moisture which happens to it, or for some other reason: then it is necessary, that he should be administered in it a cauterium with six holes, according to what has been said in the chapter on cauterization.
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	That if this is done altogether, and the ligament is loosened after seven days, and the joint does not get stiff, and the splint and stricture over it are loosened a little, and does not firm up, and falls, and cannot raise it upward: then you should know that the nerves which go to the shoulder have been cut, or extended, or made soft; and you should know that the joint never gets fixed in its place.
